transcripts.text: Listen, listen to what God's word says.  Yet you are he who took me from the womb.  You made me trust you at my mother's breasts.  On you was I cast from my birth.  And from my mother's womb, you have been my God.  Morning, sir.  What's your name?  Tony.
Hi, Tony.  Are you part of an organization that's here by yourself?
We are members of Grace Fellowship Church in Davenport, Iowa.
So... Do you think we could maybe not be so loud about our protest?
No.
Because we're getting lots of complaints about it.
I understand.  I want to make sure that the people inside can hear.  So babies are being murdered here today.
Your intention is to make sure that your voice carries inside to a property line, inside a property line, into a private establishment?

Yes.  Yeah, I want them to hear.  I believe the section you're referring to, loud and raucous noise that can be heard inside a building that was recently struck down as unconstitutional.  Tony, right?  Yes, sir.

No, Tony, actually, all I've asked is that you, I'm asking you to do me a favor and help keep the peace around here.  I mean, peaceful protests.  I mean, this country has gained so much ground over the last decades by protesting.  Some good, some bad.

But peaceful protesting is more of a word.  We're being very peaceful.  We're not threatening anybody.  We're offering people help.  And we're sharing with them the good news of the gospel.  But sir, their desire not to hear me doesn't infringe upon my right to be heard.  There is no such thing as a heckler veto.  Supreme Court ruled against that decades ago.  Well, sir, you should be interested in it because we're talking in part about the legality of what I'm doing.  So as a law enforcement professional, you should care about this part of the conversation because you're asking me to do something which at present you lack the requisite authority to ask me to do.
You're annoying everyone.  I'm asking you if you'd be interested in stopping and you're saying no.  Are we both on the same page?
We're on the same page, sir.  Yes, sir.  All right.  Have a good day.  Be safe out there, sir.
I'm going to ask you to go ahead and stop being so loud.
On what basis, sir?
Or I'm going to charge you with disorderly conduct.  I don't want to argue with it.  You can argue with the judge if you want.
Sir, I'm trying to spare you.  That law was struck down in federal court as unconstitutional.  I was the party in the case.  Your department has been briefed on this, sir.

I just got on the phone with my boss who talked to City Legal.  They have advised me that they would really, really hope that you would just stop.  But if you refuse, then you can be charged with a criminal charge of disorderly conduct.  Which one are we going to do?  Can you come to my car with me, please, sir?
Sir, a federal judge in Des Moines, Iowa, deemed this crowd, deemed this unconstitutional.
I'm not having this conversation with you.  If I'm wrong, congratulations.
